support_summary: HRD1 (also known as SYVN1) is an E3 ubiquitin ligase that is a core component of the ERAD machinery, forming a complex with VCP to mediate the retrotranslocation and degradation of misfolded proteins from the ER.

functions.cellular_process: HRD1 (also known as SYVN1) is a critical ER-resident E3 ubiquitin ligase that works in concert with VCP to eliminate misfolded proteins. HRD1 recognizes and polyubiquitinates ERAD substrates. This ubiquitination serves as a signal for the VCP-UFD1-NPLOC4 complex, which is recruited to the ER membrane. The ATPase activity of VCP then extracts the ubiquitinated substrate from the ER membrane, delivering it to the cytosol for degradation by the 26S proteasome.
functions.effect_description: HRD1 and VCP are core components of a conserved ER quality control pathway. HRD1 acts upstream to tag substrates, while VCP provides the mechanical force for their extraction from the ER.
biological_consequence: A misfolded protein is recognized in the ER → The HRD1 E3 ligase complex polyubiquitinates the substrate → The VCP-UFD1-NPLOC4 complex is recruited to the ubiquitinated substrate → VCP utilizes ATP hydrolysis to pull the substrate out of the ER membrane (retrotranslocation) → The extracted protein is degraded by the cytosolic proteasome.
specific_effects: The HRD1-mediated ERAD pathway specifically requires the VCP-UFD1-NPLOC4 complex for retrotranslocation.
This is distinct from the gp78-mediated ERAD pathway, which does not require the UFD1 cofactor for VCP function.
HRD1 is primarily responsible for the degradation of substrates with lesions in the ER lumen and some transmembrane domains.

evidence.paper_title: Different p97/VCP complexes function in retrotranslocation step of mammalian ER-associated degradation (ERAD)
evidence.journal: International Journal of Biochemistry & Cell Biology
evidence.relevant_quote: These results suggest that the Hrd1-mediated ERAD requires a well-established retrotranslocation machinery, the p97/VCP-Ufd1-Npl4 complex, whereas the gp78 pathway needs only p97/VCP and Npl4.

evidence.paper_title: Conserved cytoplasmic domains promote Hrd1 ubiquitin ligase complex formation for ER-associated degradation (ERAD)
evidence.relevant_quote: The mammalian ubiquitin ligase Hrd1 is the central component of a complex facilitating degradation of misfolded proteins during the ubiquitin-proteasome-dependent process of ER-associated degradation (ERAD). Hrd1 associates with cofactors to execute ERAD, but their roles and how they assemble with Hrd1 are not well understood.
